events.title: Birth
events.summary: Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa was born as an Italian nobleman and composer, notable for his contributions to music.
events.fun_version: Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa was an Italian nobleman, composer, and the original "drama king" of music who probably threw more temper tantrums in the name of art than a toddler denied a cookie. Known for his contributions to music, he practically invented the concept of "sorry, not sorry" with his unique compositions, which were as flamboyant as his aristocratic wardrobe! This guy was so passionate about music, he could make even a washing machine sound like a symphony.

events.title: Marriage to Donna Maria d'Avalos
events.summary: Gesualdo married his first cousin, Donna Maria d'Avalos, the daughter of Carlo d'Avalos, prince of Montesarchio and Sveva Gesualdo, and they had one child, a son named Don Emmanuele.
events.fun_version: Once upon a time in the land of family reunions gone awry, Gesualdo decided that marrying your first cousin was the perfect way to keep the family close—literally! So he tied the knot with Donna Maria d'Avalos, who just happened to be the daughter of Carlo d'Avalos, prince of Montesarchio and Sveva Gesualdo. They had a son, Don Emmanuele, who likely had to explain at every family gathering why his mom and dad looked like they could star in a "Who's Who in the Family Tree" movie!

events.title: Becoming the Prince of Venosa
events.summary: Following the untimely death of his brother, who was to become the next Prince of Venosa, Carlo Gesualdo became the third Prince of Venosa and eighth Count of Conza after the death of his father.
events.fun_version: So, picture this: Carlo Gesualdo was all set to live his life just chilling, when suddenly his brother decides to take a permanent vacation to the great beyond. And guess who gets dropped into the royal hot seat? You got it—Carlo! He goes from ‘average Joe’ to the third Prince of Venosa and the eighth Count of Conza, which is quite the promotion. All that after his dad hit the exit too! Talk about a family reunion—except it’s more like an audition for a royal soap opera!

events.title: Creative Activity in Ferrara
events.summary: During his time in Ferrara, Gesualdo engaged in more than two years of creative activity, publishing his first book of madrigals and working with renowned musicians and female singers.
events.fun_version: During his two-year stint in Ferrara, Gesualdo decided to channel his inner diva and produced his first ever book of madrigals. He was basically the rock star of the Renaissance, jamming with famous musicians and serenading female singers like it was audition day for a reality show. Who needs drama when you have harmonies, right?

events.title: Second Marriage to Leonora d'Este
events.summary: Gesualdo arranged for another marriage to Leonora d'Este, niece of Duke Alfonso II, venturing to Ferrara to further his musical career before they married and settled at his estate.
events.fun_version: Gesualdo decided it was time to upgrade his love life and arranged to marry Leonora d'Este, who just happened to be the niece of Duke Alfonso II. He thought, "Why not combine music and matrimony?" So, off he went to Ferrara—probably jamming out on the way, picturing their duet of love before they settled down at his estate. It’s like a romantic getaway, but with more lute and less sunscreen!

events.title: Return to Gesualdo
events.summary: After returning to his castle at Gesualdo from Ferrara, he established a music-making environment with a group of resident virtuoso musicians who sang his compositions.
events.fun_version: Upon his triumphant return to the royal fortress of Gesualdo after a lengthy vacation in Ferrara—where he undoubtedly dined on pasta and boasted of his musical talents—he promptly turned his castle into a five-star opera house. He gathered a bunch of super-talented musicians (who probably had some serious ear candy) to hang out and belt out his compositions. Because who needs a quiet castle when you can fill it with the sound of virtuoso voices that might just bring the walls down?

events.title: Death of his Second Son
events.summary: Gesualdo's son from his second marriage died, leading him to commission a painting for the church of the Capuchins at Gesualdo, which included figures representing his family.
events.fun_version: After Gesualdo's second marriage sent his son to the big family reunion in the sky, he decided to channel his grief into art. Naturally, he commissioned a painting for the church of the Capuchins at Gesualdo. Because what better way to express your deep family feelings than by immortalizing them in a mural? The painting ended up featuring some rather prominent family figures—all dressed up and looking sharp, because even in mourning, you’ve got to look good for the painting!

events.title: Declining Mental Health
events.summary: In his later years, Gesualdo suffered from depression and engaged in self-destructive behaviors, believed to include being beaten by his servants.
events.fun_version: In his later years, Gesualdo was like a walking advertisement for a gloomy spa retreat—suffering from depression and somehow convincing his servants to turn his home into a sort of beatings-and-bad-vibes establishment. Who needs therapy when you can take a few whacks while composing your next dark masterpiece? It was his own peculiar way of tuning into the 'suffering artist' trope, only he took it a tad too literally!

events.title: Death
events.summary: Carlo Gesualdo passed away, leaving behind a unique body of work that influenced music long after his time.
events.fun_version: Carlo Gesualdo checked out of this world, leaving behind a quirky playlist that would make even the most stoic music scholars nod in appreciation - or confusion! His melodies were like that one eccentric uncle at family gatherings, unforgettable and slightly unpredictable. Long after his departure, his tunes echoed like the last notes of a karaoke night gone awry, proving that while he may have left us, his musical legacy was here to stay!

works.title: Mentre Madonna il lasso fianco posa
Non mi toglia il ben mio
Sì gioioso mi fanno i dolor miei
Io tacerò, ma nel silenzio mio
Io parto e non più dissi
Io pur respiro in così gran dolore
Ahi, troppo saggia nell’ errar felice
